element_texts.text:
John  April 27

                                                                                                                       Milo April 27th -50

I rec' your letter yesterday.
I have sold four  bags of flour and there is four more left besides one that C B Smith borrowed.  Forest Sumner paid me for what he had.  Mr Rich had a barrel, said he would pay as soon as he got money for some hay he had to sell.
Hay is very scarce, worth $18, by the ton, and retails for £1,00 per cent lbs.  I shall probably sell 1 half tons and perhaps more.  Gould asks $6,37and a half for flour, says he buys a better brand than yours is, I thought it would not be best to rise unless it rises at Bangor, as it would fall some here when the traveling gets better.
We rec @ letter from Warren and one from Helen this week, they expected the letters would get here before father started. Mr Macomber has lost his office.  Did that  ___________ on.
I commenced harrowing yesterday.  I will put you a bag of praties, and if I can't expect Capt. Cutts to carry them down I will get Gould to, the next time he goes

To Bell
I suppose I must answer some of your questions, well the first on the pepper log was, whether or not I am too busy to come down after you, ( I think I am.)  Secondly how is the traveling (rather bad.)  Thirdly all mind?, (guess it is unless it baked yesterday), fourthly (whether I've got a hired man) I have, fifthly and lastly (is Mary at our house) she is not, she went home last Sunday, and being chosen queen for the first day of May, she has been very busy about getting ready.   The girls here have invited the boys to a picnic ball, to be had at the hall on Wednesday the 1st day of May at 5'o clock PM, requested me to be sure and earn hours in season to attend it they was going to with you if I had not,
Excuse the grammatical mistakes, for I am in an awful hurry.
John P.J
P.S I was afraid I should not get to the mill before the stage had gone and your Pate? up in a hurry may be more bad ones I have just had a letter from Father to Macomber he was at Buf when he wrote he said flour had advanced  3/8 he says the Buffalonian say that the amount that came forward is mostly small, if you want me to use some flour send word by Bell.

Milo. June 1st 1850.

Dear Brother
I recd your letter dated May 27th in due season.  The  mistake I made in my last letter came into my mind soon after it had gone, but circumstances being as they were, I thought it would not be necessary to write on that account.
Have not heard anything from the flour.  All the money that is due for flour now is for the barrel that Hamlin had.  Gould said he rec no pay at Browns for hauling praties, so I paid him $0.25.  I finished sowing yesterday.  It has been very wet here this spring, many folks have hardly begun to sow.
Our corn has been up about one week, potatoes are beginning to come up.  We have got 7 little pigs, 12 lambs.  George Knowls worked here 16 half days which about paid that note.  M. E. M. makes it her home here at present 
PS Mr Swallow at Hampden or  Bangor now.
John P. Furber
[Note: praties are potatoes]

Milo May 14th 1850

Dear Brother 
I intended to have sent this money Sat, but the stage started sooner than usual, thus I missed a bit.  I have not heard anything from the stolen flour yet, don't think I shall unless it is found by search warrant.  I rather think (as does the miller) that it went down stream.
Some one tried to break in to the first mill last Tuesday night.  I have sold all the flour that remained and we pay for all sold except one bag that Hamilton has and had dollars due on a Bbl that Mr. Rich had.
Abel Goff died day or two ago.  Mr Hamilton has been laid up with the Rheumatism bout a week.  Mr Temple is going to stay here three weeks longer.   Mehitable is going to Le Grange keeping school in two weeks from yesterday, has $2,00 per week & boarded.  I shall wind up farming about tomorrow

 J.P Furber   at the time $31,00 with care? the odd quarter ill? send some

Farmington July 24. 1857
Dear Sir,
I rec'd. a letter from your Father dated Apl 20 - last, at Milo, in which he informed me that he should leave in two days & stop at your house in Hampden two weeks, I think. I rec'd. the letter in about 3 days after writen - I immediately wrote him at your place. Saying to him that if he would let me know about the day he & family would be in Boston I would meet him there after waiting about 3 weeks I went to the City having business there about that time, but could hear nothing from him neither by [Cal. March?] nor from any other source & strange to say have not to this time. I have been delaying writing you till now expecting a letter from you or your Father every Mail, I shall expect to hear from you soon with all the particulars of your folks moving west. are you going? Our family are all in pretty good health, except I have been for a few days troubled with a lame back. suppose it to be rheumatism. am not able to do much, which makes it bad at this busy time of haying, Hay is abundant. & crops of every kind look well. indian corn is short but think we shall have a prety good crop, Shant we see you to New Hampshire this season? If you should conclude to go west I hope you will not forget & come & see us before you leave, I very much regret I could not have had the opportunity of seeing your Father & family, but if they are gone, probably I shall never see them again,
Your friend & kinsman  J.W. Furber
Written down the left side: Direct at Rochester N.H.

Cottage Grove  Jany 18th, 1850
Brother Samuel
Yours of Dec., was received two days Since, was glad to hear from you, was not aware that it had been so long since I had written you -- I have written very often of late, but I believe on reflection that my letters have all been directed to Milo, I suppose I do not always realize the fact that you are not there  I generaly intend to be punctual in my correspondence but am perhaps sometimes negligent, the fact is I am getting to have less and less time to write unless I keep late hours, Sarah's health is very poor this winter, and our little girl has been quite unwell for the last three or four months, has been more troublesome than when she was a babe. Circumstances which require much of my care, and attention, my health is as good as usual this winter, Theo, and Helen, also Olive and little one all well

you say that father meaned to sell in good earnest, but do not know what he intended doing; he writed us that he is determined uppon coming to Minnesota, if he seled I hope the mill, wish you could believe it for your interest to come to, wish you would come out in the Spring and pay us a visit if it is but a flying one, think you would be amply paid for your time and trouble
I am endeavoring to build me a comfortable house expect to finish it by june next if I do not paint, Should I paint, shall not get into it until fall, will cost me about $800, above the foundation, or wall, when it is compleated it will be paid for, I have already paid out Scince I came on to this place over six hundred dollars in cash aside from my house $200, for land $280, for team and wagon, about $200, load in lumbering the year before I came here
I made quite a raise that fall my per diem while in the Legislature (sixty days) made $360, expended about $50

I do not not reccollect the exact amt of money there was in Thea?t..d? hand? which father made us a present of. have been under the impression that I gave father the amt soon after it was disbursed, however They Sayed that he gave him the amt about that time also that he went father about four? weeks since and gave the amt again, I think it was about $186, and same cents perhaps

           When you go to Milo remember me to my old friends, Weelan Hill  Col. Lee and wife and Jon wife's family in particular  would like to see them once more   
            Sarah and the little ones send their love to uncle Sam, kiss Lucy for me and if she is not satisfied with that if she will come out here I will do it in person

Fond,  J.W. Furber
S.W. Furber

Cottage Grove Feb 29th/50
Brother Sam
I received a letter from you a fiew? days since, it seemed that you had at that time received  no letter from me seince april, there must have been some mustake somewhere, as I certainly have written you seince then, I wrote you about five? weeks seince, which you have prabaly received ere this   The mail goes out today and I have not time to write but will do so soon, all well as usual,   Regards to Lucy    Yours in haste   J.W. Furber

Cottage Grove July 15th 1850
Dear Brother
Your letter of Oct. 1st 1849 was received four days seince where the devel it had been for more than nine months is more than I can understand
Your note of the 21st April was received while father was here, in which you said you would write me more freely in a short time, but as yet I have not heard anything further from you
Received a letter two days seince from father in which there is not much of importance
We are now in our new house find it rather pleasant, and I find it is about time that we have some more convenient house, for we are getting charges uppon our house that require much and careful attention, we have an addition of a boy to our number of children, will be three weeks old on thursday next the 19th
Hellen's Mother and sister have been with her ten days, the old lady I believe is rather discontented

Seince father left here we have had very wet and warm weather, for the week last past the mercury had stood at about 95 degrees in the shade at noon, every thing is growing speedy and finely, I have a few hills of corn in my garden that was planted about the 25th of May, and it had been in full silk for a week, I should suppose from present appearance that it might be ripe in about four weeks now
I have been very busy in finishing my house all the fre? part of the season, and am now cutting my hay, my grain harvest will come on in about two weeks, and our full electioneering campaign is just opening, expect to be mixed up in it to some extent, after the canvas is over I will give you the details
I have been mowing to day, and it is now between 9 and 10 o clock in the eve and I must bid you good night.
Say to Lucy that we expect to see her out here before many years, I think she must have her hands full to take care of all her children, cows pigs and chickins, you should be very attentive and help to rock the cradle
Remember me to all my friends there are many of them I should like to see
Joseph, W. Furber

Cottage Grove Oct 10th 1850
                                                                                                                  Thursday Evening

Dear Sir

         I suppose you would like to know that those fire fraims were received. Well they came to hand about two weeks scince, not in good order however, they were all three of them broken. Haskell's was broken Square across the Cap, can be straped? two were both broken in the fronts. I have managed however to set them. I think they had been rough handled, but in the first place were badly packed. was not packing enough between the plates, they bore uppon each other, and that not eveanly. I am however exceedingly glad to receive mine even as they are, they are an new article in the west. I wonder that our western founderys do not cast them. I think many of them would be used, if they could be obtained conveniently, mine are much admired. The charges on the box when they arrived at Point Douglass were only $9.45

[upside down] Received a letter from Sam a short time scince, also from Father. John must send this to them as in answer

                                                                                                                                                         J.W. Furber

We have just received a very pleasant visit from Mr. Garfield and family (Wife and one daughter from Ohio, Mrs. Garfield and Sarah are sisters, had not seen each other for about eight years. Mr. Garfield lives in Chillicutta is Worth from $30 to $35,000.00 his incum from bank stock is about $1,600.00 incum an broakering business from $12 to $1,500.00 tho he keeps no office as a broker, owns a goat farm within one mile  of the city on which he lives worth from $8 to $10,000.00 they spent ten days with us, left last Monday.

         We have had a must delightful fall, the potatoe crop is the only light crop we have, and that is rotting. I raised about 100 bush. from 7 bush. seed a part of which were somewhat rotten when I dug them, have not roted any scince.
               Theodore commences ploughing on Monday next with two teams for Jon? I scorched down the grass this spring 3 acres directly east of my first peace of timothy, Will scorch down two or three acres more in the spring directly North if you wish it, that panic grass is no go
              Money is tight yet, still the mill has lumber from $11 to $12

I raised a fine lot of pumpkins in my garden, but they are rotting badly and in order to save some of them I have been cutting and drying, have my North front room well furnished at this time I can assure you.

        Almost every good locatin in this township is now taken up, on this side of the timber there is but one vacant ? between Norris and Patten, on the West Side the is not an acre along the timber that is vacant
        I have not seen Judge Meaker scince he returned. he has however sent me now that he wanted that 40, When I see him if he want it enough to fork over $500. for a deal he can have acre
        I think it would be well to have this east 40 entered? I think of preempting the 80 West of one covering the Lake and a small strip on the West side of it I expect I can preempt , if so it will give me a year to ? in. I am beginning to think that this 80 may be thought y some one valuable
         Should I enter I presume that I can get $50 back by letting the Branson place to the Water.

J.W. Furber  Oct
We had a call yesterday from the Rev McHall the Presbyterian minister has just arived had a family of a wife only, a young man of very good address, and appearance he supplied this place and Pt Douglass only, proposed to hold forth in each place, each Sabbath, or politically speaking Sunday I believe Theo has engaged to board him and his lady @$4. pr week, Will he not have quite a house full of women and not any children to comfort them, Well as troublesom as my children are I think I would as soon have my house filled with them as with any others
Our folks here are all well as usual Estella is almost always well so long as she can romp and run, Aurilla's health had been better for the last three weekes than it has been scince  spring, I think as cold weather comes on she will improve, the little boy has not yet got a name, but had had the offer of many, is yet very troublesom, is not well but gromed quite well, think if he had a healthy mother, that he would be a good boy
Joseph W Furber

Cottage Grove April 18th 1851

Scince I last wrote you I have been to the land office at Stillwater and made application to purchase two of the parties? that Smith has covered by land warrent, but I found that to make my application good the money must be deposited with the receiver otherwise the application could not go on record, not being able to deposit the money I have had to let it rest.

   I expect Smith here in the course of three or four weeks and I am of the opinion that he will be ready to arrange the matter satisfactorly, as he must be fully aware that he never can get a title. ? the two parties uppon which I have improvements, by his land warrent. If disposed however he might withdraw the location of his warrent and enter with the money. 
    When I last wrote you I made an allusion to the probability of my being absent from home for a year or two to come, those probabilities however have become as one of the things that ? I remain at home.

Mehitable  February 10

                                                                                                                                                        Sunday morn.  Feb 10th 1850

Sister Lucy
It is very rainy today, and I suppose there will be no meeting.  I was learning all last night about letters, which put me in mind when I awoke that I ought to write to you.  I believe I am getting rather negligent about writing it seems quite a task to sit down and write a letter, but I will endeavor to write enough at least to still the voice of conscience which has been upbraiding me for a long time.
I have  been keeping school seven weeks, have had a vacation of one week to be sick in, am now quite well.  I do not know how much longer my school will be, I write very much better than when I left before, still I have some trials,  but perhaps they are no greater than are to be met with  in almost any situation of life.  I believe there is no cup of enjoyment but what has bitter dregs mixed with it at least I have always found it so.  I have an excellent boarding place at Mrs Smiths.  I feel perfectly at home here and I could never be contented where I did not.  I did not go home yesterday afternoon, it rained some and I was very busily engaged mending a green jacket for Mr Smith it was terribly torn and Mary had to hand it over to the old maid!  She thinks it a great wonder that a young  girl like me should like to mend; but I do if I can get something that is badly torn.
We received a letter from Warren last week, his family were not very well, he says if I will not go out and

spend the summer with him, he will pay my expenses out, what think you of it?  I guess I shall not go till we move.  I do not dare to think of moving much.  Sometimes I dream of starting, of leaving all the friends and associations of childhood, and I wake sad and dispirited, but I trust that if we go the pain of the real parting will not equal the imaginary one.
Mr Jones is going to Hallowell to preach, he will have the pastoral care of a church, he has $500 per year.  I believe he starts in about three weeks, will not move his family till warm weather.  I suppose there will be no preaching here for the present, I do not know what this place is coming to, rum and gambling over everything.  How does John prosper?  I suppose his term is nearly out.  When are you coming to Milo?  I want to see you.  Have you been to Palmira?  If so how did you like the folks?  I hear that Joseph is on his way home, and no better poor man I pity him.
I suppose you will call this a short letter, but I am getting cold and hungry.  I should like to come and see you after my school closes, but think likely the traveling will be too bad.  There is a man here taking minutes, I have not seen any of his specimens but understand they are very nice.  Perhaps I'll get mine to leave with you when I go West; Mr Haskell has his farm to Mr Buswell.  Write soon won't you.  Good by.
Mehitabel

Mehitable June 16

                                                                         La Grange, June 16th/50

Dear Lucy,
Here I am in La Grange the last place that I would have believed (when I left you this spring) that I should pass the Summer in - how little do we know of the future - how happy for us that it is hid from us.  I am very well contented here, much better than I expected to be, I have a very pleasant school of about forty scholars, have about a dozen girls from 12 to 15 years of age that try my patience some - they are not ugly but they do hate to study - and it is trying to have to keep talking to girls of their size.  I can have a great deal more patience with smaller ones - I have five Carver children they have been set-off into this district; among the rest is that same Edward I have heard you tell so much about.  He is certainly as uneasy as a child conveniently can be, but - I do not - discover anything ugly about him.  I board with the widow Herrick, the next house below Mr Fullers and about half a mile from the school house, it is a very good boarding place, no children, a new house, and very pleasantly situated.
There is preaching here once in four weeks by  Mr Strout of Bradford, which is all the meetings they have.  I suppose that John is at Hampden ere this, want to hear

from him.  Father and Mary E came down to see me the next day after he got home, guess I was a little bit glad to see him, was very sorry to hear that you had been sick, hope you have got well by this, I went up home last Saturday, and father has promised to come after me again in about four weeks, I keep school every other Saturday.  I can go home Friday night and so make quite a visit;  I do wish I had those books I didn't get when at your house, have you read any more of David Copperfield?  If so, report progress when you write will you?
Suppose father told you all about our farm in Minnesota.  I cannot realise that we are to go so soon.  I went in imagination the other night and was very homesick;  but "Drams  always go by contraries" you know, I have some idea of coaxing father to leave me on the farm if he does not-sell.  Think Bose and I could manage it?  By the way Bose came down to see me when father did and I could keep him out of the schoolhouse which  pleased the young uns much.  My school will close the 10th of August if it keeps but eleven weeks I have got some acquainted with the Fullers, very pleasant people.
Write soon as you receive this would you, the mail does not go but once a week from here, goes down Tuesday and up Wednesday, so I shall have to wait till next week for an answer be sure not to disappoint me then.   Make John write to me if you see him.  I want to know what Sammy? is doing.  Give my love to marm. Crosby and Marggy.  have you got that box made?  yours affect  Bell Furber

La Grange  July 11th/50
Sister Lucy
I have just drawn off this pattern for you which I ought to have done before I came down here but was so hurried that I forgot it. Shall have it for you to ink as I have no pen suitable a quill being best for that purpose I suppose -

I received your letter a long time after it was written but it was nevertheless very acceptable. John's came to hand more readily. I did hope to go home last Wednesday night and remain the rest of the week, but the weather not permitting, was obliged to wait till Friday night  Had a nice visit - Mary and Henry brought me down Monday morning - So you and Sammy have been up to Milo - should have thought he might have come down and seen me - suppose your health was not good enough Am very sorry to hear that your health is still so poor -  Many thanks for the books you left for me, what kind friends books are! always ready to entertain you - the people here seem to be very kind but the ideas of some of them seem not to rise much higher than the top scaffold in their barn. How beautifully the fields look now with their waving grass. I never expect to see home clad in its richest garb of beauty again - we may be disappointed however - I cannot tell whether I should regret it or not

Sunday night, Oct 6th 1850
Dear Sis Lucy

Feeling "sort of lonesome" tonight, thought I would scribble a little to you. Somehow it seems so long for the society of brothers & sisters tonight - more than usual - I want somebody to talk to - It was rainy this morning so I did not go to meeting. Mr Strout preached   Suppose there will be no preaching next Sunday unless our new minister comes about which there still seems to be some doubt. There is some talk of our boarding them if he comes, but I dont want them a bit especially his wife, we have'nt any conveinences for boarders in the first place, and then I hate to have a woman round  I think I have read somewhere that one should never write anything in a letter that one was not perfectly willing for everybody to see - but I think it is a rule not often followed - at least by me -  I have been very busy ever since my school closed and suppose I shall  be as long as we stay here - have been preparing stocking yarn making a rug  sewing rags quilting and knitting jacket. I finished mine last week - it is very pretty sets as slick as a mitten  I shall knit yours this week if nothing happens, am afraid I shall not get it the right dimensions dont know at

Mehitabel Oct.
to be any different from mine except in the length of
the waist and sleeves, & stuffed one of my dresses
to try mine on to when I was knitting it.  Getchel 
colored the yarn for me, he got a first rate color -
there will be about 24 skins of worsted left, and there
will be some yarn left do you suppose I could work
them into a hood?  I shall need one and if it is not
very pretty it will answer, I have been afflicted
with the jumping toothache a little while most 
every day for about three weeks.  I thot I knew what
the tooth ache was before but I never had anything that
half equals this while it lasts I went to the Doctors
yesterday to have it out but he was not at home
don't know as I can muster courage enough to go
again, tis so dark I can't see the lines so good night.
Tuesday morning, we read your letter last night and
I must hurry and close this to send out this morning.
I shall send you $18,00 dollars of my school money
which I have just rec, shall not probably want
it till spring, How shall I send your jacket
Lucy, when it is done?  I should think you would
need it soon - hope to finish it this week-
Julie Hartwell and Henry Getchel intend marriage
in about a week, I think going to live in the Wyman
house this winter.  Mr Hartwell has been very sick
every since he came home from the conventions.
Had a letter from Warren last week, all well except the hog he is
either sick or cross as fury can't know which.  I should like to write more but can't stop
this morning.  Joseph Hill was here last week, Abby's Fred is expected home this month  Marshall Hill is married

Saturday eve. Dec 7th 1850
Probably if I had been "severely talked to" it would
have made me so contrary that I should not write at all
but as I do not consider myself thus reprimanded, I will
endeavor to report to your satisfaction.
I have been at home one
week, had a fine time at the institute, boarded with Mrs. Woodbury
formerly Lizzy Power, they live opposite Ellen Greeleys, a very pleasant
family.  Mr Power has changed invitations with Mr Stevens who
keeps the boarding house at Foxcroft, expects to move to the
village soon - Mary is in Charleston Mass.
Proff Sheperd delivered three
lectures before the institute, very interesting indeed, preached
sabbath day in the academy - Mr Eaves(poor weak mortal!)
undertook to find fault with his lectures, probably they were
too deep for his comprehension, I suppose you remember
the "young maidens and their beloved's"; which were
so pathetically spoken of at the picnics!  Margrett Crosby and
her brother were at the institute a few days, she is a good
girl isn't she?  Mr Parker was President, what a funny man
he is sometimes; we were reading one of Ms. Candle's 
curtain lectures one day; Mr Humphrey told the ladies to
read it in earnest, yes said Mr Parker "the women will
make that go"!

Did you know that Harriet Chamberlain was dead?
She was married and lived in Dover, had a miserable
husband.  They have a new Freewill Baptist meeting house
in Dover.  The congregationalist-society are going to build
one near the academy, where Mrs Greeleys house stood.
Our new minister, in the shape
(not of a parttridge) but of Mr Pattridge was here to day
he appears very well but is not such a man as Mr
Wilson,
I rec a letter a short time since from Eliza Hayes
of Farmington, in answer to one that I wrote to Mrs. Chandler.
Eliza was boarding there and attending the institute-
Aunt-Page died at Rochester a few weeks since she was
the last of the family, Uncle Jonathan Wingate of Parsonsfield
died in November aged 92 he also was the last of that 
family-the  rest of our friends there are well as usual.
Hingman Furber was just - one year from the time he
started in reaching California.  Do not know how 
he has prospered since he got there.
We have rec no letter from
Alice since last spring, what can be the reason that
she does not write?  Have rec two from Warren this week, as
folks are all well.  Ms Clara Williams (Mr Haskells sister)
died a short time since after an illness of about two days
Theodore boards the minister and his lady, Mrs Hale and
Emma are there, they have a house full of women-
Warren says that Governor Ramsay is very anxious for

him to go to Washington this winter and that if he does
not receive something there to pay him for his expenses,
that he will see the bills posted, Warren wrote that if he went
it would be necessary for him to start very soon and he
did not see how he could leave home at so short-notice
if he goes we shall expect him here on his way back.
How does your jacket fit Lucy? or haven't
you tried it on yet?  I think a hood and comforter out of the
leavings, took the liberty to finish up every bit of your worsted!
I have made me a nice warm shawl, got -Mrs Hamlin to 
weave in - and Getchel to color it wine color- have commenced
a hearth rug don't know when I shall get a chance to finish
it, have got the rose and trimmings some is very pretty
show that figure that you had on that piece of paper -
have made me a new dress this week, plain waist, looks
first rate-I propose to work Sammy a pair of slippers some
time this winter like some Mrs Everett has been working for
Charles, they are very handsome, I suppose you will have
no objections Lucy will you?  Father has just brought out
the bass viol and that "Ancient Harmony" I almost - wish
every one of those tunes was annihilated!  We sung from the
Dulcimer at the institute, there are some excellent tunes
in it - Mr Morrell is teaching singing school there, has about
sixty scholars, they make some music I assure you -
Mr Hartwell does not get any better so we can perceive
think it very doubtful if he ever does - Theophilus Sargent
and Abby Rollins (Mrs Hartwell's sister) are published-

[at top]:
Mehitable  ?
What are you going to have for Thanksgiving?  Wish you had one
of our turkeys!  Perhaps Father will come down with a load if it is good
sleighing, though I should judge from the sounds now issuing from
the viol that whoever made them would not be able to go out again
very soon.  How does John prosper in his school?  I feel very anxious for him
I have not yet forgotten the first school I taught though I trust he is more
pleasantly situated, you must give him all the good advice you can?
[at bottom]:
Mother is yet quite lame I cannot see that she has gained any for the
last three weeks she has a bed in the kitchen, the baby couldn't sleep
upstairs this winter.  What about David Copperfield?  Has it all been published?
I think you cannot in good conscience ask me to write another letter
for at least one month
When are you coming to Milo?  Is Samuel going into the woods this winter
[at bottom - upside down]:
Monday. it was cold and blustering yesterday; very few out to meeting
Think Mr Pattridge will be liked very well, shall expect a letter from Leuey? soon
as she is able to write,   Sis Bell
[on right side]:
This is horrid writing but I trust you will peruse it, I have been
knitting some of the queerest looking stockings you ever saw - don't know 
that is very closely connected with the subject, but the stockings are not as
closely knit - give my love to Margrett, and to Ann, want to see her.
[in middle]:
Mr Samuel W. Furber   Bangor  Maine

May 14

What a beautiful morning, isn't it?  Really seems like summer, Mary E is
over here, spect we shall go maying by and by - the people all thought
I had gone to Minnesota when I went to Hampden, wish they had
not found out to the contrary, Mr Lane started to come after
me to take the school in the Stonefield district, when he got
to the village he was informed that I had gone west so he went
back, tis just as well I should not have wanted to keep there -
We have not heard from Father since he was at Mr Wingates-
John had a long letter from him written while there, I believe
he lost Niles Carver in Boston.  He went to Mary Sykes's in
Worcester, she is getting along well, has five of the prettiest children
he ever saw, her husband sent her a thousand dollars from
California last winter, Lucy Gould & her husband are saving every
cent so they say to emigrate to the West with, Father says Gould
appears to be a fine man.  Mrs Hale and Emily had not got along
He met Mr Haskell in New York, he is going right up where the
boys are - Mr Temple will probably stay be three weeks longer
believe he is liked very much, he lived in the island of Malta

till he was twenty years old.  Hannah Brown that was - is but just 
alive - Mr Hatch from Le Grange came here Saturday after me to 
keep the school at the corner, it was sometime before I could
make up my mind to go into the town again, but the almighty
dollar two of em a week, overcome my scruples - and I told the man
I would go.  The school will commence week from next Monday.
continue eleven or twelve weeks -  I have been half repentant ever
since - but will try and make the best of it - I hope you will
write often.  you know what a remedy letters are to the diseased
organ of Inhabitiveness, when are you coming up? wish you would
come before I go away - What is the prospect now of Samuel's getting
work? want to hear - good by
Bell Furber

Cottage Grove, June 23rd 1851.
   Dear brother Samuel,
              I intended to have written to you ere this, but have neglected it. I suppose though that father has kept you informed of our proceedings - we got here safe, but not very sound, two weeks ago yesterday, our journey across Illinois was very tiresome and very lengthy, the roads were horrible - the rest of the journey I enjoyed very much, we met Theodore and Hellen at Point Douglass, they were expecting us. I hardly knew Theodore at first, - he is as bald as you are. I have been trying to persuade him to get a scratch. Monday we all went over to Olive's - we found her with two babies, the youngest is now seven weeks old, I think - her oldest, Hellen is the dearest little creature you ever saw, looks very much like her mother and Mary E. I wish you could see her, she jabbers all the time but I cannot understand much she says. Olive looks just as she used to, only perhaps a little older, she seems very happy, but I do not think that I have heard her laugh - well I suppose there's no sense in laughing, but I do enjoy it vastly sometimes - but I cannot find anything here very often to laugh at - or else I'm so homesick that nothing will please me - however I feel quite as well contented on the whole as I expected to, but sometimes I have such longings for my home and native land - and when I think how widely we are separated - how can I help being homesick?

June 9th they had not got there then - we need them very much- we expect a cook-stove this week, soon as it comes we shall put it in the log house, cook and eat there, and have one room here to sit in - twill not be very convenient but better than to cook - over the same stove with Sarah, she is very kind but to have three noisy children under ones feet is not very pleasant. I should like for you to have the training of the two girls awhile, mother was over to Olive's three or four days last week they brought her home yesterday. Theodore and Emily were here, we had

a fine sing, wish you could have joined us, or rather wish we could have
joined you, for I don't think you would be contented here or would better
your circumstances by coming, and such as I should like to live near you
I would try and not be so selfish as to advise you to come while I thought it
would be to your disadvantage - though of course I am not a competent judge
in the matter of acquiring property - but I do not see that the people here enjoy
themselves any better than they do East.  Mr Shaw of Exeter made his
appearance here yesterday, don't know whether he intends to buy or not
he asked father to day if you was coming out here I wanted to tell him
you was a goose if you did -  but contented myself with thinking so -
Alfred and John are getting out stone for the cellar wall - we are in hopes
to get up something in the shape of a house to live in this winter - 
I suppose you will think by my writing that I am very dissatisfied
with the country - well I am with somethings, but there are others more
favorable - probably I have not been here long enough yet to know whether
I shall be contented or not - Theodore's folks have a large family.  Mr Hale
and his wife board there, and they have two half-breeds to educate and a man
that has taken part of his farm boards with him.  Mrs Hale is there now.
Emily is teaching at Point Douglas, they have congregational preaching here
half of the time the meetings have been held in Warren's log house
but they will be moved now to another vacant house, they need a school
house a meeting house here very much, do you remember that Patten?
that used to live on Mr Lee's farm?  he lives now not but a little way from
us - I have had one horseback ride rode about four miles - wasn't that
doing pretty well for the first time?  Emma and I talk of riding over
to Olives if we can get the houses, Em is having two weeks vacation now
it is the hardest work to ride in their waggons here.  they are great double
go carts I call them, Theodore has a buggy but it is out of repair -
we are going in search of strawberries tomorrow, they are ripe but not
very plenty here I think -tis time to set the table for tea I mus put
this away now and finish it sometimes this week, the maid will not go
out till Saturday we looked for a letter from you last week but was 
disappointed, we are very anxious to hear from Lucy

Friday 27th, The mail will leave tomorrow and I must close this today
we set up our cook - stove yesterday, our log kitchen looks quite nice and comfortable.
I don't know the rain may affect it - believe it - leaks sometimes -
O dear the mosquitoes have swarmed here for the last - three days it does seem
as though we should be eat up alive.  I thought I knew something about them
before I came here but find I was mistaken they just spoil the country
in my way of thinking.  Mother seems quite disappointed I am afraid she
repents of coming, she said to me since I began to write - "I suppose you
wont advise Samuel to come here."  I told her of course I shouldn't, well
"I wouldn't either" she replied, I don't know much about the society here
Hellen says there is some very good, Theodore drove over a cow and calf 
the other day and made a present of it - to mother, we bought one of 
Haskell paid $30 are obliged to let the calves have part of the milk all summer
to bring the cows home at night - It seems as though I ought to fill this
sheet - but the children are in here turning the books, topsy-turvy and
the flies bite so I am about half crazy, do write often I want to hear
from Lucy, how does the damsel  Frances get along? and how does the
steam mill prosper? and the vessels?  I want to hear all about it.  Father has
gone to St Paul today coming back tomorrow by Stillwater. Have you heard
from Lizzie Doe?  She left us at Buffalo I should like to know how
she got along.  I think I shall go over to Olive's next week and stay two or
three weeks perhaps if I don't get homesick, she calls her baby Mary Elizabeth
she is a very good child, Warren calls his boy William Henry, Olive
says she wrote to you soon as she got your letter after Lucy was taken sick
last fall, but I think you never received the letter. Mr Haskell
is very kind and pleasant and a great talker says he should not have
known me, Theodore did not know John, well good by - don't imagine
me homesick all the time only once in awhile when the fit comes over me.
Your affect sister
Mehitabel

Mehitable
Cottage  Grove  August 8th 1851
Dear Sister Lucy

We received a letter from you last week, you don't know how rejoiced we were to hear that you are getting better so fast - You must mind your mother and not be too smart - I wrote to you soon after we got here but it seems you had not received the letter when you wrote = am afraid it is lost - your last letter came in fifteen days. Poor Mr Hartwell is gone - I can hardly realise it - Lucy is truly deeply afflicted - her mother and husband both taken - what will she do with her little children?  How much he will be missed in Milo - especially by Charles and Mary - I want very much to hear particularly about his last days - I hope to have a letter from Mary this week, father had one from Mr Hamlen last week  He thinks Milo is rather gaining on the whole - I am very glad to hear it - I think I shall always take more interest in that place than in any other. It seems that Waterman has taken his better-half home - how many changes happen in a short time - I suppose we notice them more when we are absent.   I am at Theodore's now have been here about ten days - I love to stay here. I think he has the most pleasant situation of any of our people - his house is on the open prairie & like it better than the grove - it is so damp at Warren's seems as though it could not be healthy - my trunk is covered with mold in the sitting room - we have a fine breeze here all the time too which keeps off the musquitos in a measure - Theodore has ten acres of corn in one piece in sight of the house it does look handsome - but is rather backward, the season has been so wet and cold - grain looks finely, is about ready to harvest - The treaty is at last concluded with the Indians so when they are removed they will be far enough from us - they do not trouble us here any now - I have not seen one since I came here - but there are lots of half-breeds -

[on side]: I wonder if I have said all you want to know - I suppose there are a thousand questions you would like to ask that I have not anticipated  I am sorry to hear that Sammy is so poor - you must take a trip out here and fat up like enough I'll go home with you when you come  I almost want to go with Mrs Hale and Emily, I should think Isaac would want to come up here and see the country, now he is so near  Well its most time to get dinner, give my love to all the folks - Albina and the little ones  write often  all the comfort I take is in looking forward to mail day  Yours affectionately  Mehitabel

Hellen's health is very poor this summer - the excitement she has been in ever since she came here seems to have died away and left her low spirited. Her mother and Emily are going to start for the East about the first of September. Mr French has sent for Emily to come and keep house for him, she feels so much for the children that she thinks she must go. Hellen is very much opposed to it. I do not wonder that she wants to go back, but it seems to be taking a great deal of care of? herself -- she has been teaching at the Point? for sometime = Mr. Hall, his wife and Hellen have gone to the Point today and left me to keep house. I wish you could come in and chat with me awhile - it would be much better to have some help than for me to do it all. Mr Hall & his wife are very pleasant people, they have boarded here almost a year. He is from Ipswich ?, she is from New York. He preaches here half the time, has but one sermon - after that a bible class?. We have Episcopall? preaching once in four weeks - the Bishop was here last sabbath - he did not put on his white robe suppose he thought it would not look well in a log house - Mrs Hall's brother was here three or four days a short time since.  Mr Chapin - he is President of Belloit colege in Wisconsin-
he is a very pleasant man and a very good speaker-
Olive was over to meeting last Sunday -Bishop [Hernper?] thought we had quite a family choir - you and Gammy should have been here - but  for your own sakes I am glad that you are not - I can't think that you would be contented - at least here in the farm country.  I dont know how it would suit you at St. Paul or St. Anthony.  St Anthony is said to be a beautiful place and growing fast.
Well it is pleasant enough here as for that matter but it is not New England.  We were very much surprised a short time since at the appearance of John Tenney  & his wife - they have taken up their abode at St. Anthony for the present.  Our goods have not yet arrived.  We feel somewhat worried about them.  I guess Mother often wishes she was in ? but she does not say much about it, she thinks that after we 
get our house built - she will be contented.  I hope she will but I have not 
the least idea that  I shall.  I guess John gets rather homesick - sometimes but he never says much
he can get along very well when it is fair weather, but soon as it rains he is all down to the heel  - he has bought a piece of land and broke
ten acres.
Hellen rec a letter from you a short time since she intended to write some in this but I think she will not get back in season.
Olive's health is rather poor of late, I am afraid she is troubled with bronchitis - Mother is well, says she never had such an 
appetite in her life.  I of  course am always well unless I  m ? sick.

Cottage Grove Sept 19th 1851

My dear brother

                      I suppose that ere this reaches you, you will have

received the sad news of dear mother's death, to day we have followed
to his long resting place Warrens little boy - our darling Millie - she has
been sick for some time was teething but we did not think to find dangerous
he died yesterday, very unexpected to us all, he was about fifteen months
old, he was a darling child, I never saw anything look as pretty as his corpse
did, white as snow, with the blue veins on his forehead just as his fathers
used to look, he was a great favorite of mothers, and has followed her
to a better world, O, Samuel you can think how lonely we all feel, I know
it will be heavy tidings to you to hear of mothers death, but you
will not miss her every, hour and minute as I do, it seems sometimes
that I cannot live without her, but I know she is better off what is our
loss is her gain, she died so peaceful that I cannot make it seem like
death, she seemed not to have a single regret at leaving.  I asked her a short
time before she became speechless what ;we should tell Samuel:  she
said "tell him that - I bless him to the last", and again she said
"I am dying, but I can give you all up, tell Samuel I can give him 
up."  Her funeral was attended by Rev Mr Peal of St Paul, his text was
from Philippians 1st 21st "To die is gain."  I have forgotten the mo of the
hymns, but the first line of such was "How blest the righteous when (unclear)"
and "Dear as then went, and justly dear"  She never looked more pleasant
than when she was laid out, it seemed as though she must be in a
sweet sleep, her strongest - earthly wish seems to have been gratified
to die among her children I don't know as she could go in a better

time.  I don't think she would even have been contented while she lived.
She looked forward to the time when we should get into our own
house with a great deal of pleasure, but she might have been disappointed.
Warren received a letter from you last week written
the 25th of June - it had been to Cottage Grove Wisconsin, I have had
but two letters from you one of those was a month coming, perhaps
if you put on the whole direction they would come sooner.
Cottage Grove Lake St, Washington Co, Minnesota, I have not
got that bookmark yet that Lucy promised me, hope she will
send it, Our goods have not got here yet, am afraid they will be
spoiled if they were to come, father has written to Boston twice but we
no answer we shall probably keep house this winter but hardly
know what to do yet - it does seem as though I could not stay
here now, though for fathers sake I must try and content myself
at least for the present - I don't know either, that I should feel any
better if I went back East it would not be home there now.
It seems sometimes as though i was left all alone in the world but
I know - I ought not to feel so - my friends all love me enough, better
than I deserve, but my mother - who can fill her place!  It is growing
dark and I must see to the things, write often your affectionate sister
Mchitabel,

Cottage Grove  Oct - Nov 4 1851
Dear Samuel & Lucy

Your kind letter was received week ago last Saturday, also Mother's miniature - we all think it a perfect likeness - you were very good and kind to send it. I am so glad she had me taken - Father started last Friday to go after his goods, I don't know when to look for him because it is uncertain where he will find them he may have to go nearly to Chicago, and he may meet them on the river - we did not dare to wait any longer for fear the Lake would freeze and we should not get them this Fall - they have been a constant source o anxiety to us ever since we have been here - I have looked for them so many times that I almost think sometimes they never will come; but I must learn to wait and be patient - we have felt the need of them very much - Theodore and John have gone up to the Fort today to have an experienced surgeon look at John's arm - I am very fearful he will have a stiff arm - Alfred is to work at Theodore's today and I am left to myself - I have washed, and eaten my solitary dinner and now have nothing better to do than to write to you - how lonesome it looks here - there is no kind smile to greet me when I look up and ask me what I am writing to Samuel but silence and sorrow are my companions - everything looks gloomy - the sky is cloudy, and the wind blows cold and chill rustling the dry leaves about our dwelling - Images of the past come thronging bout me - I see the "Old house at home" and with it all the pleasant associations of childhood and youth - I see the happy household band - I hear the kind voice of my Mother  Oh! can it be that voice is hushed forever? But I must drive these thoughts from me - We trust that our Mother is now happy in Heaven, let us strive to walk in the "straight and narrow path" looking with an eye of faith to Him who is willing and able to save all who come unto him - then we may hope to meet her there. Oh, what a blissful moment when the friends long severed on earth, shall meet in heaven - I feel that this hope is mine - I trust that through the merits of Him who died to save us, my sins have been forgiven  what a blessed hope that when our earthly pilgrimage is over we shall be received into the presence of God our Savior - Sometimes the thought comes

what if I should be trusting is a false hope:  Pray for me, that I may not be
left to the wishes of Satan, but may scorch my heart and know whether I have
yielded it entirely to God.
I went over to Olive's yesterday and spent the
day-wish you could have been with us-she has everything comfortable
and a very kind husband - it seemed so pleasant to sit down by then chestnut
fireplace when it came evening and have him read to us while we scared - the
babies were fast asleep so there was nothing to interrupt us - Little Hellen
is a darling child - she was two years old last Saturday - I wish you could see
her she says "Aunt Bell" and "Uncle Dodolo" - We are in hopes to move
over to Theodore's in two or three weeks as father has perhaps told you.
I am anxious to go it will be much for comfortable and I think
the evenings will be more pleasant - they are very dull here - sitting
down in this dark gloomy cabin usually with a thick cloud of
tobacco smoke almost choking me - but I will try and be patient
and hope for better things when we got our new house.  I don't know
when that will be if John should have a stiff arm I don't know
whether he can work on a farm too much advantage, should
think he could attend to some other business better.  Father needs to
have some of the care taken from him he has grown so childish
I never saw one fail so fast as he has since last spring.  I know 
it was too much of an undertaking for him to come here.  but I
suppose he would not like to admit it - I think sometimes that
he had better rent his farm and not try to do so much that is 
if John is not able to work but I don't know what he will think
of it.  I wish you were here to advise him - I always think that your
advice is right - but perhaps I am a little partial - Well I shall want to
write some more often Joh gets back so good by today.
Wednesday PM John got home this morning - the Dr thinks his arm will always
be some stiff but may get so that he can use it considerable - he told
him to shower it twice a day in tepid water and rub it in wrm
whisky and volatile liement says, the condiles of elbow are injured
I don't know what they are but had quite a snow storm last night
but it has most all melted today - Everybody is driving business it a great

Olive April
Prospect Grove April 1850
My dear brother and sister
when I look at the date of your last letter, my heart reproaches me severely for neglect; and yet I will not even promise to do better for fortune favors me with many things to do, but I might have devoted some stray moments exclusively to you, do not think that for a day you are forgotten; in passing through my daily routine of duties "Fond memory is busy still" and in her wings I'm with you still hue?" but alas! recollection at hand soon hurries me back not to despair, but reality hope and joy.
I think I have never written you of our prairie flower that we are cultivating carefully, tenderly to blossom in immortality be assured I feel the responsibility that rests on me Oh that wisdom might be granted me to train aright. With this ease Lucy, there is a delight a mother only can know My darling is quiet and good natured has never cried in the night since she came here, wakes at 7 or 8 in the morning laughs and talks to herself until I am ready to take her then I give her some breakfast and kisses put her to bed she goes to sleep again and sleeps two or three hours then gets up for all day she goes to bed awake every night indeed I cannot remmember when she has gone to sleep in my arms when she is sleepy put her on the bed or sofa go out of her sight

and she will usually go right to sleep, She has waked from her morning nap I hear her whispering, nothing more. Dont you wish you had one? I do, you being to think you'll hear of nothing but baby, a little, and Im done, we call her Helen, Mehitable is the middle name; has black eyes & hair weights now 13 1/2 lbs six months old first of May and is the prettiest child in the world, of course. Sister Helen spent last monday with me I read your last favor to them was glad to hear of continued health and prospects has good angels guard and attend you ever. Poor Jo, he must then give up all hopes of recovery must resign himself to utter helplessness It would seem at first that earth could have no joy for him but then it must great joy to have friends to minister to his necessities how many in his situation would have to suffer and die unbefriended without even the consolation of religion my regards and sympathies to him altho almost personally unacquainted yet I like him for I know he has been a good brother to our dear Lucy. Well I guess I cannot write any more to day should have been sewing carpet rags had I not been writing. How are you going to get it wove I hear you say. Am going to send it, not to Mrs Sargent but below to somebody 
May 5th Father come week last Monday; he can tell you every thing 'bout us but I suppose I'll send this very interesting letter Little darling sends many kisses in return for her pretty socks wish we could send something more tangible, but cannot seem to get hold of

anything "proper" unless it be a live Gopher Mr Haskell has
two or three in a :barl  I suppose (unclear) would raise some
objection to the amount of fodder they would require on their journey
in the shape of potatoes, carrots, &c
How cold it is, freezes every night never such weather was
known here at this season before.  John sent me two pieces of his
music we sung them up to Mr Bruntwell's they are real melody
have you seen any of his composition in music I mean.  Wish
I could write music I long for some new pieces I have sung my
favorites all to pieces, ception "Nancy & Jimmy, The spoons suit
me to a te perfect beauties what a nice cup of tea I can have.
Have just finished a while linen bonnet for darling she is
now armed and equipped "cepting a cloak and I want you
to write me what I shall make of, and how.  I believe a babys
cloak is the only thing I never did make or attempt to.  The "Hills
shadows lengthen, and baby's winkings ditto, good night.
Baby's winking having suddenly come to a close I resume - 
I have a little half breed girl with two black eyes some eight
years old came home with Sunday from Theo's will stay a few
weeks she is a proper good little girl. Helen is teething and a little 
troublesome but Jenny tends her nicely.  Grand pa thinks that daughts
has a wonderful head.  Did you even read Mrs Clavers New home
who'll follow?  Mrs Boutwell lent it me it is prime "fuss rate"
as our Henglishman says.  We are "quine to have a cook room
added and our sitting room finished this summer when we
get rich we will have a front put up but this when finished will be
much as we will need for some years.  A kitchen woodshed sitting room
bedroom & nursery here is the plan

(Diagram of house)    What you think on it
There is a darling piece of poetry in my
March Repositry that I want to send you
I do not know enough to judge of its mento
as a composition but I know tis' just the song
I'd write, an I could.  Do you poetry any
now a days Lucy, or was you Farewell to the muses
a real meant to be farewell.  Isn't my Prairie flower a fine subject
for (not clairvoyance) but for, for - I can't think of any pretty word to put
there, but you know what I mean, for you to poesy about.  But here is 
what I like so well
"Yes, sister, I am happy                                                                          How can I but be happy?
For Heaven upon my path                                                                      There's a merry little sprite,
Has scattered all the treasures                                                               Whose fond caress awakes me.
Affections garner hath;                                                                           With the early morning light;
And the sweet and thrilling music                                                           She brings her white arms round me,
That I best love to hear                                                                           And, with  a joy half wild,
The tones of love and tenderness-                                                          I press her closely to my heart-
Are thrilling in my ear.                                                                             My own, my darling child

                                                        ------------------------------------------------------------
How can I but be happy                                                                        How can I but be happy!
There's a bright and earnest eye
Whose glance to me seems brighter                                                     There are loved ones far away,
Than a starbeam from on high;                                                              Where the mingled lights & shadows
And that is getting ever                                                                         Oer the green valleys play;
Oh! So tenderly, on fire;                                                                        And, tho in their dear presence
And I never, never look in vain,                                                              I often long to be,
The lovelight there to see                                                                      I know that in their far off home
How can I but be happy?                                                                      They often think of me
There's a voice whose every tone                                                         ------------------------------------------------------------
Can make within my spirit
Sweet music all it's own
And that voice is ever near me,                                                              There, I suppose you rather I'd copy than
To counsel and to cheer                                                                         to send blank paper.  Forgive me for neglecting
Breathing quiet words of love and trust                                                  you so long, but I've so many works to do
Into my listening ear                                                                               He get some eatables cooked and think He have

                                                                                                            a fine time to write and read and mend and
                                                                                                            make, when bounce will come some men for dinner
                                                                                                            or worse for supper, lodging & breakfast, then action
                                                                                                            fond dream of delight it evaporates in tobacco
                                                                                                            smoke the (unclear) minute came yesterday I
                                                                                                            just had to drop my pen to take a farewell shake.

My love to Almeda Mr Haskell
is jabbering over a message to
Sam & Lucy about love, and driving
business to support his wife
& baby and promises to write a 
whole letter by himself Goodbye

Prospect Grove Feb 28th '51
Dear Lucy
Yours mailed Jan 21st, (My birth day) arrived last evening. I was so glad to hear from you, to receive another letter from your own hand, I was fearful I never should and promised to learn your recent affiliation in the departure of another dear one to "the shadowy hand" to be with us no more but to be happy and blessed forever. You'll meet them there, your brother and babe, in perfect joy. 
Oct 24th 1851
Dear Brother & Sister
You see that I commenced this many months ago and now I can only write what you probably hear thru others. What changes a few months has brot to me - the birth of a hair haired daughter. The meeting again dear ones - happy hours spent with a mother now no more - happy hours not to be [?] but in memory. Oh the agony of the thought never to see her face again. Dear dear mother she is gone - gone to a better world than this. You can imagine the vacuum her death has made. Cannot realize it until you go to the cabin where she lived and sit at the table where she presided. You can then feel the force of that word. Gone. Just the few past months have brot life and death joy and sorrow.
My little ones are well; the the babe we call Mary Elisabeth

I wish I could have more favorable accounts of your health
Lucy.  It requires a good deal of patience for me to be confined
three or four weeks  my health is good now I did not get up
from my confinement so well as when Helen was born.
I have a little half breed girl that helps me a good
deal altho she tries my patience sometimes.  My family is large
most of the time two and three men beside my husband.  Tis fortunate
perhaps that I have children, and a good deal of work to do
for the moment I have time to think my mothers sickness and
death are before me what bitter bitter hours they were to us
but death had no terrors for her.  She could not talk much.
I asked her what we should tell Samuel "Tell Sam the Lord
Jesus" - the rest was inaudible.  She breathed her last 
sweetly as an infant on its mothers breast.  It seems as tho
I had just begun to know her worth, had just begun to love
her when she left us.  She over here and staid three or four days
three weeks before she died.  The last I heard her sing was "Why
not stretch thy wings and fly.  To yonder world of joy.
Father looks like a shadow I suppose he has written
you there is a prospect of his getting the goods.  They have written
you of course of John's sad accident poor fellow I'm fearful he
will have a stiff elbow.
I must beg forgiveness for neglecting to
write you hope you will not take pattern by me, or think it is a lack
of love -children bring many cares and works.  Mr Haskell was
very sick the last of August two or three weeks.  Helen was sick
two months with the summer complaint we despaired of her life

part of the time and during the whole I could get no help.
We are having a cold snap just now it freezes all the
day.  We are having a bedroom finished a hog house hen house
and work shop and grainery built - all under one roof.  I do not
mean the bedroom included.
Joseph's brother Aretas has been here
started for home week ago quite feeble he was sick with us
nearly three weeks confined to his room most of the time but not
to his bed excepting the first week he could not lie down at all.
You will write me won't you, notwithstanding
my negligence I wrote you a letter last winter which it seems
you did not receive.
Jenny fails to keep baby quiet - so
I must leave.  I hope I shall see you sometimes.
God bless you my dear
brother and sister
Yours ever
Olive H. H

Milo, Oh!
I send herewith you Brandymans
papers, also G IV Wingates note - you are a little
to late for me to charge Wingate $050 for deed.
I had settled the business before receiving your letter.
I have sold no flour since you was up Gould
had it to sell, but I believe he is out now
and is sleighing is about "done up" I think
I shall sell some room.  I may not sell enough
to pay me before I start as I intend to be off

I have partially bargained away your farm to day to William Owen.
I offered it to him for $300 in cash payments as you and he might
agree, he said if you would take your pay in thick boots 60
wholesale prices he would buy it, he said the price this year would
be $2,50 if the price varied in future so be it-
he did not say what part he would pay this fall or winter
I think you had better sell it the field is so run out
that it will never be worth mowing until it is 
plowe'd - he wants you to write me your best terms
by return mail, Direct your letter to me, say that
he must pay the school house tax and if he want to can let
him off on that, get as many boots in the first pay & as 
you can coax him to - your notes should be on int
for dollars payable in boots at wholesale price
he his his boots shall be equal to Lakes first quality of
boots both in stock and workmanship and
refers you to Walter Brown & Goos and Upham as

Milo October 28th -- 50
Yours of the 27th imt was rec'd to day, We are verry sorry to hear that Lucy is so verry sick and glad to hear that she is some better - Hope she may soon recover Since writing you I have been on the East half of No 5 Range 5 East half of Boston north and adjoining Brownsville for the purpose of dividing said East half. PB Mills of Bangor petitioner - went last Wednesday got home last night was out through the whole storm with nothing but a Blanket for a covering through three rainy nights, On my arrival home I found your mother better than when I left - the soreness which was in her leg just below her knee seems to have removed into the joint but is decidedly less painfull and sore, the fact of the removal of the diseas induces us to believe that it is simply rheumatism, this relieves our apprehensions of a diseased or decaying bone Doctor M has great hopes of her recovery She is now verry comfortable, but little paine goes about house but little, her confinement to her chair is her greatest trial

I suppose that Doct N would rather give two months services than for her to go abroad for medical aid, that however would make no diference with me, but as she is evidently improving I have at present no wish so to do - from the above statement you will not expect to see her at Bangor on Tuesday next as I wrote you in my last, if she was well she would go to assist you but under existing circumstances it would be highly improper as she can not or ought not to wait upon herself or others -
I am apprehensive that John works too hard at his studies I have no doubt  but he is making extraordinary progress, he is ambitious and means to excell if possible, I am of the opinion that he has made such proficiency that with the aid of Books he may become well acquainted with Geology, Mineralogy and Chemistry - his knowledge of Mathematics Surveying &e is respectable and qualifies him well to teach those branches in all of which he may make great improvements by devoting his Leisure hours to study

I do not think it good economy for me to go after him it will cost more than double his stage fare, if he does not obtain a school before the expiration of the Term at Hampden it will be best for him to attend the Institute at Dover (Nov 18th) in that case he ought to come home by Fridays Stage Nov. 15th if he takes a school it may not be necesary for him to attend the Institute at Dover, I shall send him some money to meet his bills, and wish him to write me this week, hope you will see him-
Your Mother sends by Givins a few dried apples Call at Franklin House 
What is pork (round hogs) worth in Bangor my hot will weigh 3,50 or more I think what she gains now is not worth the cost
J,P,Furber

Milo Nov 22 -- 50
I have been to see Owen three or four times to fix up that sale of land but have been as often put off, yesterday he said that he wanted a diferent arrangement, did not want to give notes payable so far ahead, he wants a bond for a deed running one year the conditions to be his paying $100 at or before the expiration of this year giving notes for $100 each payable in one and two years - the bond to be forfeited, as also all payments made previous provided he does not comply with the terms The reason he assigns is that if he should die before a year that his Estate would be unencumbered by notes - I think his reasons are without good foundation, it is a mere whim, but I see no injury resulting to you provided he gives as he says he will security to pay you $50. or more dollars independent of the amount named in the bond because whatever he pays will be forfeited and you will get that much from the use of the place - if he should neglect or refuse to comply with the conditions of the bond - Another thing, he wants to let you have as many harnesses as you can dispose of, he has quite a quantity of that kind of stock on hand and Gliven gives him the making - now I think you had better take 50 or 75 worth of harnesses if you can sell

Milo - Sabbath day
Dear Mother
We were abominably disappointed
sorry, and badly grieved not to receive any
latter from you the past.
Being on an independent turn of mind myself,
I were very strongly inclined to hold my
piece, and say we could get along if you could.
But Joseph, who you know habitually tyrannizes
over me, imperatively requires me to write
to send the major who is going down to
carry John tomorrow (unclear)
We must respectfully request you to bring up 
Lucy and yourself as soon as possible.
We are a good deal persecuted here in your absence
by mosquitoes, Almeda &c.  I keep things pretty
well under control generally, but Almeda
is sometimes refractory, coming in upon us and
in spite of my most strenuous exertions, turning
up red, in shape of washing, mending &C
the mosquitoes we wage war upon generally.
The warmth of the sun Joseph say is endurable
when the wind blows.  (It doesn't trouble him.)
He also testifies that he has no evidence
that he has not been getting better ever since
you went away.

When are Mother & Lucy coming up?
Why do you come!
There is no doubt though the we were never in so much
prosperous and comfortable condition as at present in spite
of Mrs Kitters and Almeda; So you need not think you
must hurry home on any of our account.
I am afraid you might possible be most as bad as Almeda's
Respectably
A. S (unclear)

Packet boat C$5.00 and boarded - all well, Bell was sea side

We have all been to see the Niagra Falls - Grand night
